Chief Complaint: cardiac arrrest s/p trach placement
   24 Hour Events:
   Patient recieved one unit of packed RBC overnight for dropping
   pressures.  Patient neuro status continued to improve. Patient now
   following commands, opening eyes and responding appropriately to verbal
   stimulus. Reports no pain.  Have not yet been able to wean off the
   ventilator.

   Troponin-T:[**Numeric Identifier 374**]//, ALT / AST:294/568, Alk Phos / T Bili:40/0.9,
   D-dimer:2257 ng/mL, Fibrinogen:367 mg/dL, LDH:777 IU/L, Ca++:6.9 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.2 mg/dL, PO4:2.1 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment & Plan:63 y/o M with PMHX of MM s/p autologous stem cell
   transplant in 05 presented foot pain and elevated CKs taken the OR
   emergently for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome, now s/p cardiac
   arrest and emergency tracheotomy.
   .
   # s/p Cardiac Arrest: Etiology unclear, may be due to acute upper
   airway swelling and hypoxia causing cardiac arrest/bradycardia. Pt had
   rapid return of perfusing rhythm.  There was significant concern for
   initial poor neurologic status post code, however, pt has now had
   return of neuro function and following commands. Suspect that meds
   given peri code contributed to poor neuro status initially, now
   clearing.
   - replete lytes aggressively, status post aggressive Ca [**Last Name (LF) 375**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**]
   follow-up repeat labs
   - neuro exams appear to be improving
   - no need for cooling currently
   .
   # Resp failure: Pt was transferred to ICU s/p cardiac arrest with
   emergency trach and was initially requiring alot of support from vent
   to maintain oxygenation but now weaning quickly.  There was likely a
   component of negative inspiratory pressure pulm edema as seen by
   perihilar fullness on CXR.  This is also suggested by the fact that pt
   weaning quickly from initially high O2 requirement. Also with some
   increased secretions from emergency trach and blood in airways.
   Etiology of tongue swelling early on [**10-1**] and impressive upper airway
   edema seen by Anesthesia impeding the ability to re-intubate is
   unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 11**] have some component of airway collapse and tongue swelling
   from hypothyroidis. Baseline, pt is a Mallampati class III and may have
   pharyngeal airway collapse complicating picture.  Now have definite
   airway with trach, will hold off on steroids for now given mild e/o
   immunosuppression.
   - wean oxygen/PEEP as tolerated
   - continue aggressive suction
   - [**Month (only) 202**] RR to improve respiratory alkalosis
   - empiric Abx Vanc/Cefepime/Clinda/Doxy for any possible pericode &
   emergency trach aspiration
   - Alb/atrovent nebs
   - NPO for now, SBT with trach collar in am
   .
   # Compartment Syndrome with abscess: Pt has now had definitive surgical
   intervention with fasciotomy and frank pus found after opening
   compartments.  Deep cultures were sent intra-op
   - continue Vanc/Cefepime/clinda for skin flora and ?immunocomp state,
   will cover gram negatives until cultures return, then narrow Abx
   - f/u cultures
   - f/u ID recs, work up for atypical infections
   - f/u Vasc Surgery recs
   - dressing changes per Vasc
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Pt presented with hyponatremia of unclear etiology, may
   all be secondary to hypothyroidism.  Appears clinically euvolemic to
   hypervolemic currently, no prior h/o SIADH.  Pt having alot of urine
   output currently, it is possible that this hyponatremia & hypochloremia
   is due to volume overload.
   - continue NS IVF
   - serial lytes q6hrs
   - f/u urine lytes & osms
   - continue to treat hypothyroidism
   .
   # Multiple Myelomma: Pt has been on Revlimid which may have been
   contributing to hypothyroidism on admission.  Anemia & thrombocytopenia
   on admission likely due to marrow suppression.
   - holding Revlimid currently
   - f/u Onc recs
   .
   # Elevated CK/Rhabdo: This was likely all secondary to compartment
   syndrome with intracompartment abcess, now s/p fasciotomy
   - continue aggressive IVF, keep UOP>100cc/hr
   - monitor creatinine & f/u renal recs
   - continue local wound care per vasc
   .
   # LFT abnormalities: Elevated transaminases & elevated LDH in setting
   of acute rhabdo. Baseline LFTs normal.  Unclear if this is due to
   atypical infection vs acute rhabdo.
   - trend LFTs
   - f/u hepatitis serologies
   - f/u ID recs & atypical infection work up
   .
   # Anemia: Hct was 34.7 on admission, now down to 25. This is likely
   complicated by underlying abnormal bone marrow on revlimid for MM and
   intra-operative blood loss.
   - transfuse to maintain hct>25
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Pt profoundly hypothyroid with TSH>50 and low T4.
   This may be contributing to tongue swelling on admission.
   - apprec endo consult
   - continue Levothyroxine 200mg IV daily
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now
   - aggressive repletion of lytes
   .
   # Access: Right femoral line placed during code under non-sterile
   conditions, Left PIV and right arterial line.
   - plan to d/c fem line in am
   .
   # PPx: Pneumoboots, H2 Blocker, Colace
   .
   # Code: FULL
   .
   # Dispo: ICU
   .
   # Comm: husband [**Name (NI) 366**] [**Name (NI) 367**] (h) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 370**], (w) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 371**], (c)[**Telephone/Fax (1) 372**]

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male who underwent an autologous stem cell transplant for multiple myeloma and presented with foot pain and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels. He was taken emergently to the operating room for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome and developed cardiac arrest during the procedure. He was resuscitated and intubated, and an emergency tracheotomy was performed.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Neurologically, he is improving, able to follow commands, open his eyes, and respond to verbal stimuli. He reports no pain.
* Respiratoryly, he is still on mechanical ventilation, but weaning is progressing quickly. He has a tracheostomy tube in place and is being suctioned aggressively.
* Cardiovascularly, his blood pressure is stable, and his heart rhythm is sinus rhythm.
* Hemodynamically, his central venous pressure is normal, and his blood volume is being repleted aggressively.
* Renally, his urine output is adequate, and his creatinine levels are being monitored.
* Metabolically, he has hyponatremia, which may be secondary to hypothyroidism or volume overload. His thyroid function is being treated with levothyroxine.
* Infectiously, he has compartment syndrome with abscess, and deep cultures were sent intra-operatively. He is being treated with antibiotics, and his wound is being managed with local care.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he is still on mechanical ventilation. Weaning may be challenging, and he may require prolonged ventilation.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's cardiac arrest was likely caused by acute upper airway swelling and hypoxia. He may be at risk for further cardiac events if his airway edema persists or worsens.
* Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing infections due to his immunosuppressed state and the presence of an abscess. He is being treated with antibiotics, but further infections may occur.
* Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's elevated CK levels may indicate ongoing rhabdomyolysis, which can lead to renal failure and other complications.
* Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may worsen if he continues to have volume overload or if his thyroid function is not adequately treated.
* Complications of tracheotomy: The patient has a tracheostomy tube in place, which may lead to complications such as tracheomalacia, tracheal stenosis, or tracheitis.
* Wound complications: The patient's wound is being managed with local care, but he may be at risk for wound infection, dehiscence, or other complications.

The patient's care plan includes:

* Aggressive repletion of electrolytes
* Weaning from mechanical ventilation
* Continued treatment of compartment syndrome and abscess
* Management of hyponatremia and hypothyroidism
* Monitoring of renal function and creatinine levels
* Treatment of potential infections
* Wound care and management of potential wound complications
* Close monitoring of the patient's respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological status.

   .

   perihilar fullness on CXR.  This is also suggested by the fact that pt

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still requiring ventilatory support, and there is a risk of further respiratory failure due to the underlying conditions, such as compartment syndrome, hypoxia, and airway edema.
2. Cardiac Arrest: The patient has had a cardiac arrest, and there is a risk of recurrence due to the underlying conditions, such as hypoxia, electrolyte imbalance, and sepsis.
3. Compartment Syndrome: The patient has had compartment syndrome, and there is a risk of recurrence or progression of the condition, which can lead to further tissue damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
4. Sepsis: The patient has had sepsis, and there is a risk of further sepsis or septic shock due to the underlying conditions, such as compartment syndrome, hypoxia, and airway edema.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, and there is a risk of further electrolyte imbalance, which can lead to seizures, coma, and potentially life-threatening complications.
6. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient has had rhabdomyolysis, and there is a risk of further muscle damage, which can lead to acute kidney injury, electrolyte imbalance, and potentially life-threatening complications.
7. Pneumonia: The patient has had a history of pneumonia, and there is a risk of further respiratory infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia.
8. Sternal Fracture: The patient has had a history of sternal fracture, and there is a risk of further complications, such as sternal instability, respiratory compromise, and potentially life-threatening complications.
9. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has had thrombocytopenia, and there is a risk of further bleeding complications, such as hemorrhage, due to the underlying conditions, such as compartment syndrome and sepsis.
10. Anemia: The patient has had anemia, and there is a risk of further anemia, which can lead to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues, fatigue, and potentially life-threatening complications.

The patient's ongoing care should focus on addressing these potential complications, including:

* Monitoring for signs of respiratory failure, cardiac arrest, and sepsis
* Maintaining adequate oxygenation and ventilation
* Managing compartment syndrome and rhabdomyolysis
* Correcting electrolyte imbalances, including hyponatremia
* Managing bleeding complications, including thrombocytopenia
* Addressing underlying conditions, such as compartment syndrome, sepsis, and pneumonia
* Providing supportive care, including pain management, nutritional support, and wound care.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is on invasive ventilation and has a high risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to the emergency tracheotomy and prolonged intubation.
2. Compartment Syndrome: The patient has a history of compartment syndrome and may be at risk for re-occurrence, especially with the ongoing use of vasopressors and sedation.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen and lead to further complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and cold intolerance.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to ongoing bleeding, blood loss, and inadequate transfusion.
5. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's rhabdomyolysis may lead to further complications, such as acute kidney injury, electrolyte imbalances, and cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing infections, especially with the emergency tracheotomy and prolonged intubation, which can lead to sepsis, septic shock, and multi-organ failure.
7. Cardiac Arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrhythmias may worsen and lead to further complications, such as cardiac arrest, ventricular fibrillation, and cardiac failure.
8. Neurological Complications: The patient's neurological status may worsen due to ongoing hypothyroidism, anemia, and rhabdomyolysis, which can lead to further complications, such as seizures, coma, and brain death.
9. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's gastrointestinal system may be compromised due to the emergency tracheotomy, which can lead to nausea, vomiting, and bowel obstruction.
10. Fluid and Electrolyte Imbalances: The patient's fluid and electrolyte imbalances may worsen due to ongoing bleeding, blood loss, and inadequate transfusion, which can lead to further complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and seizures.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma, hypertension, and hypercholesteremia who presented to the ICU after a cardiac arrest and respiratory failure. He underwent an emergency tracheostomy and was found to have an abscess that required a fasciotomy. The patient was initially severely hypoxic and unresponsive but showed improvement in oxygenation and mental status overnight.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: The patient is on invasive ventilation with a tracheostomy tube, receiving 550 mL of tidal volume, and a respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's blood pressure is 108/62 mmHg, and his heart rate is 69 beats per minute.
* Neurological: The patient is sedated and not able to provide a history, but his mental status has improved overnight.
* Renal function: The patient's creatinine is 1.1 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 25 mg/dL.
* Hematological: The patient's white blood cell count is 1.6 K/uL, and his platelet count is 72 K/uL.
* Coagulation: The patient's international normalized ratio (INR) is 1.1, and his partial thromboplastin time (PTT) is 29.2 seconds.
* Liver function: The patient's alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is 294 IU/L, and his aspartate aminotransferase (AST) is 568 IU/L.
* Electrolytes: The patient's sodium level is 135 mmol/L, and his potassium level is 4.2 mmol/L.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he requires invasive ventilation to maintain adequate oxygenation.
* Sepsis: The patient has a history of abscess and is receiving antibiotics, which increases the risk of sepsis.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and the etiology is unclear. This could be related to underlying infection, post-arrest physiology, or other factors.
* Rhabdomyolysis: The patient has a history of multiple myeloma, which increases the risk of rhabdomyolysis.
* Hyponatremia: The patient's sodium level is low, which could be related to underlying medical conditions or fluid imbalance.
* Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of cardiac arrest and may be at risk for cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or cardiogenic shock.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and improve his clinical status.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma, hypertension, and hypercholesteremia who presented to the ICU after cardiac arrest and respiratory failure. He had a tracheostomy and was intubated. Overnight, his oxygenation improved, and his mental status also improved. He received multiple IV antibiotics and IV fluids. His current vital signs are: temperature 37.5°C, heart rate 69 bpm, blood pressure 108/62 mmHg, respiratory rate 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 97%. He is receiving invasive ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and FiO2 of 50%. His arterial blood gas results are: pH 7.44, pCO2 39 mmHg, pO2 71 mmHg, and HCO3- 25 mmol/L. His laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 1.6 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 8.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 72 x 10^9/L.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, and he is at risk of developing further respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein suggest the possibility of sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's elevated creatine phosphokinase level suggests the possibility of rhabdomyolysis, which could lead to acute kidney injury and other complications.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia could be related to underlying infection, cardiac failure, or other medical conditions.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism could contribute to his respiratory failure and other complications.
6. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein suggest the possibility of infection, which could lead to sepsis and other complications.
7. Cardiac failure: The patient's cardiac arrest and hypotension suggest the possibility of cardiac failure, which could lead to further complications.
8. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine level suggests the possibility of acute kidney injury, which could lead to further complications.
9. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal distension and bowel sounds suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal complications, such as ileus or obstruction.
10. Skin breakdown: The patient's immobility and increased risk of skin breakdown suggest the possibility of skin breakdown, which could lead to further complications.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the patient is a 72-inch tall, 118.3 kg male who was admitted to the ICU following a cardiac arrest, tracheostomy, and bilateral compartment syndrome. The patient has been experiencing rhabdomyolysis, with elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels, and has been treated with antibiotics, including cefipime, vancomycin, doxycycline, and clindamycin.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 38.1°C, heart rate of 71 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 129/71 mmHg. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 550 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 10 cmH2O.

The patient has been experiencing respiratory distress, with a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and has been treated with bronchodilators and oxygen therapy. The patient's oxygen saturation is 98% on 50% fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2).

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, creatine kinase, and troponin-T levels, indicating possible cardiac damage. The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, with elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels.

The patient's physical examination reveals right conjunctival edema, bloody tracheostomy, and decreased bowel sounds. The patient's extremities are swollen, with 2+ edema in both legs. The patient's skin is warm, and the patient is able to move both legs, but has difficulty wiggling toes.

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and the patient is requiring mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiac damage: The patient's troponin-T levels are elevated, indicating possible cardiac damage.
3. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's creatine kinase levels are elevated, indicating muscle damage.
4. Compartment syndrome: The patient's extremities are swollen, and the patient is at risk for further compartment syndrome.
5. Infection: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and the patient is receiving antibiotics.
6. Liver damage: The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, indicating possible liver damage.
7. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating possible kidney damage.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy to support the patient's respiratory function.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac function and consider further cardiac testing, such as an echocardiogram.
3. Continue antibiotics to treat possible infections.
4. Monitor the patient's liver function and consider further liver testing, such as liver function tests.
5. Monitor the patient's renal function and consider further renal testing, such as a creatinine level.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's compartment syndrome and consider further treatment, such as fasciotomy.
7. Consider further testing, such as an electrocardiogram (ECG) and a troponin-T level, to evaluate the patient's cardiac function.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment & Plan:63 y/o M with PMHX of MM s/p autologous stem cell
   transplant in 05 presented foot pain and elevated CKs taken the OR
   emergently for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome, now s/p cardiac
   arrest and emergency tracheotomy.
   .
   # s/p Cardiac Arrest: Etiology unclear, s/p epinephrine x1, CPR for 3
   minutes, may have been due to acute upper airway swelling and hypoxia
   causing cardiac arrest/bradycardia. Pt had rapid return of perfusing
   rhythm.  There was significant concern for initial poor neurologic
   status post code, however, pt has now had return of neuro function and
   following commands. Suspect that meds given peri code contributed to
   poor neuro status initially, now clearing.
   - replete lytes aggressively, pt is hyponatremic, still unclear
   etiology
   - serially neuro exams
   - would like to elucidate etiology of cardiac arrest better
 most
   likely etiology is hypoxia, with history of upper airway swelling would
   consider allergy/angioedema, would also consider PE as well as
   hypotension, sepsis
   - cooling protocol was deferred secondary to improving neuro exams
   - echo from yesterday did not show any evidence of right heart strain,
   mild LV hypertrophy, LVEF 50-55% with dilated aortic root, ascending
   aorta moderately dilated, small pericardial effusion
   - goal is to maintain MAP > 60 and maintain urine output > 100 cc/hr
   .
   # Resp failure: Pt was transferred to ICU s/p cardiac arrest with
   emergency trach and was initially requiring alot of support from vent
   to maintain oxygenation but now weaning quickly.  There was likely a
   component of negative inspiratory pressure pulm edema as seen by
   perihilar fullness on CXR.  This is also suggested by the fact that pt
   weaning quickly from initially high O2 requirement. Also with some
   increased secretions from emergency trach and blood in airways.
   Etiology of tongue swelling early on [**10-1**] and impressive upper airway
   edema seen by Anesthesia impeding the ability to re-intubate is
   unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 11**] have some component of airway collapse and tongue swelling
   from hypothyroidism. Baseline, pt is a Mallampati class III and may
   have pharyngeal airway collapse complicating picture.  Now have
   definite airway with trach, will hold off on steroids for now given
   immunosuppression.
   - cont hypoxia may be secondary to atelectasis vs. fluid overload
   secondary to volume repletion vs. Pulmonary embolus
   - wean oxygen/PEEP as tolerated however gases have been limiting us
   overnight (mental status is not a barrier to extubation)
   - will bring PEEP to 10 this morning
   - echo today to rule out blown RV which might indicate PE to explain
   etiology of hypoxia
   - continue aggressive suction
   - decreased RR to improve respiratory alkalosis, new ph 7.44
   - empiric Abx Vanc/Cefepime/Clinda/Doxy for any possible pericode &
   emergency trach aspiration
   - Alb/atrovent nebs
   - NPO for now, working on SBT with trach collar in AM
   .
   # Compartment Syndrome with abscess: Pt has now had definitive surgical
   intervention with fasciotomy and frank pus found after opening
   compartments.  Deep cultures were sent intra-op
   - continue Vanc/Cefepime/clinda for skin flora and ?immunocomp state,
   will cover gram negatives until cultures return, then narrow Abx
   - appreciate ID recs
 ID thinks that this might be a global process,
   reccomending west [**Doctor First Name **] serologies, stool enterovirus, ebv viral load,
   ebv, cmv, hav, hbv, hcv, lyme [**Doctor Last Name 376**] serologies  - HIV testing
   then consider viral load, also MRI
   - if goes to OR would consider muscle biopsy, repeat bacterial cx,
   viral cv
   - f/u cultures, try to get viral cx
   - dressing changes per Vascular
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Pt presented with hyponatremia of unclear etiology, may
   all be secondary to hypothyroidism.  Appears clinically euvolemic to
   hypervolemic currently, no prior h/o SIADH.  Pt having alot of urine
   output currently, it is possible that this hyponatremia & hypochloremia
   is due to volume overload.
   - continue NS IVF
   - serial lytes q6hrs
   - f/u urine lytes & osms
   - continue to treat hypothyroidism
   .
   # Multiple Myelomma: Pt has been on Revlimid which may have been
   contributing to hypothyroidism on admission.  Anemia & thrombocytopenia
   on admission likely due to marrow suppression.
   - holding Revlimid currently
   - f/u Onc recs
   .
   # Elevated CK/Rhabdo: This was likely all secondary to compartment
   syndrome with intracompartment abcess, now s/p fasciotomy
   - continue aggressive IVF, keep UOP>100cc/hr
   - monitor creatinine & f/u renal recs
   - continue local wound care per vasc
   .
   # LFT abnormalities: Elevated transaminases & elevated LDH in setting
   of acute rhabdo. Baseline LFTs normal.  Unclear if this is due to
   atypical infection vs acute rhabdo. Suspect that may continue to worsen
   today as patient is s/p cardiac arrest.
   - trend LFTs
   - f/u hepatitis serologies
   - f/u ID recs & atypical infection work up
   .
   # Anemia: Hct was 34.7 on admission, now down to 21. s/p 1 unit
   transfusion overnight.This is likely complicated by underlying abnormal
   bone marrow on revlimid for MM and intra-operative blood loss.
   - will transfuse another unit this AM, re-check crit and consider
   furthur
   - transfuse to maintain hct>25
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Pt profoundly hypothyroid with TSH>50 and low T4.
   This may be contributing to tongue swelling on admission.
   -          continue Levothyroxine 200mg IV daily
   -          endocrine does not think hypothyoidism is the etiology of
   patient
s presentation
   -          cortisol level pending
   .
   # FEN: NPO for now
   - NG tube today, nutrtion consult for tube feeds
   - NS fluid 150 cc/hr to maintain UOP > 100 cc/hr
   - aggressive repletion of lytes
   .
   # Access: Right femoral line placed during code under non-sterile
   conditions, 22 and 20 IV
   -          PICC line today, plan to d/c fem line pending picc line
   placement and stable blood pressure
   -          Consider central line for better access
   .
   # PPx: Pneumoboots, H2 Blocker, Colace, mouth care
   .
   # Code: FULL
   .
   # Dispo: ICU
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma, who presented with foot pain and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels. He was taken to the operating room for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome and was found to have a frank pus in the compartments. He had a cardiac arrest during the procedure, which was successfully resuscitated, and was intubated and taken to the ICU.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

1. Cardiac arrest: The etiology of the cardiac arrest is unclear, but it is suspected to be related to hypoxia, upper airway swelling, and possible allergic reaction or pulmonary embolism.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient required mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy, but is now being weaned off the ventilator.
3. Compartment syndrome with abscess: The patient had a fasciotomy and was found to have a frank pus in the compartments, which was cultured.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia of unclear etiology, which may be related to hypothyroidism or volume overload.
5. Elevated CK/rhabdo: The patient's elevated CK levels are likely related to the compartment syndrome and abscess.
6. LFT abnormalities: The patient has elevated transaminases and LDH levels, which may be related to acute rhabdo or atypical infection.
7. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is likely related to underlying bone marrow suppression and intra-operative blood loss.
8. Hypothyroidism: The patient is profoundly hypothyroid, which may be contributing to tongue swelling.
9. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient has rhabdomyolysis, which is likely related to the compartment syndrome and abscess.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac arrest and hypoxia may have caused cardiac damage, which could lead to arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to hypoxia and respiratory acidosis.
3. Infection: The patient's compartment syndrome and abscess may lead to infection, which could spread to other areas of the body.
4. Renal failure: The patient's rhabdomyolysis and compartment syndrome may lead to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's hypothyroidism and rhabdomyolysis may lead to neurological complications, such as seizures or paralysis.
6. Septic shock: The patient's compartment syndrome and abscess may lead to septic shock, which could be life-threatening.
7. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's hypoxia and respiratory failure may increase the risk of pulmonary embolism.
8. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's hypothyroidism and rhabdomyolysis may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male who presented with foot pain and elevated CKs, leading to an emergent fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome. He then experienced a cardiac arrest and was intubated with a tracheotomy. The patient was transferred to the ICU, where he is currently being weaned off the ventilator. He has undergone multiple surgeries, including a fasciotomy and debridement of his right leg, and has had persistent elevations in his CK levels.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is still a concern, with ongoing need for oxygen support and weaning from the ventilator. There is a risk of respiratory failure if the patient's oxygenation and ventilation do not improve.
2. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest is still unclear, but it is suspected to be related to hypoxia and upper airway swelling. There is a risk of recurrent cardiac arrest if the patient's underlying cardiac condition is not addressed.
3. Compartment Syndrome: The patient has had multiple surgeries to address compartment syndrome, but there is still a risk of recurrent compartment syndrome if the patient's compartments are not adequately decompressed.
4. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's persistent elevations in CK levels suggest ongoing rhabdomyolysis, which can lead to acute kidney injury and other complications.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is likely related to hypothyroidism or effective volume depletion, and there is a risk of worsening hyponatremia if the patient's underlying condition is not addressed.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely related to underlying abnormal bone marrow and intra-operative blood loss, and there is a risk of worsening anemia if the patient's underlying condition is not addressed.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient's profound hypothyroidism is likely contributing to his respiratory and cardiac symptoms, and there is a risk of worsening hypothyroidism if the patient's thyroid function is not adequately managed.
8. Infection: The patient's ongoing elevations in CK levels and LFTs suggest ongoing infection, which can lead to sepsis and other complications if not addressed.
9. Renal Failure: The patient's ongoing rhabdomyolysis and hyponatremia put him at risk of acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease if not adequately managed.
10. Wound Complications: The patient's wounds are at risk of complications such as infection, dehiscence, and delayed healing if not adequately managed.

The patient's ongoing management should focus on addressing these potential complications, including optimizing his respiratory and cardiac status, managing his compartment syndrome and rhabdomyolysis, and addressing his underlying anemia, hyponatremia, and hypothyroidism.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 38.1°C (100.5°F), a heart rate of 81 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 121/67 mmHg. The patient is receiving oxygen therapy and is on a tracheostomy tube with a ventilator mode set to CPAP/PSV.

The patient's laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, a decreased platelet count, and an elevated creatinine level. The patient's electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with a low potassium level and a high magnesium level.

The patient's medical history includes a history of rhabdomyolysis, which is still active and is being treated with fluids and bicarbonate. The patient's temperature has been elevated overnight, and vancomycin has been discontinued.

The patient's plan of care includes continuing to monitor his CPK levels, continuing fluids with bicarbonate until his CPK levels decrease, and discontinuing vancomycin. The patient will also continue to receive other antibiotics and will be monitored for fevers.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration.
* Sepsis: The patient's elevated temperature and abnormal laboratory results suggest that there may be an underlying infection.
* Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's ongoing rhabdomyolysis can lead to further muscle damage and potential kidney damage.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's abnormal electrolyte levels can lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
* Infection: The patient's elevated temperature and abnormal laboratory results suggest that there may be an underlying infection.

In conclusion, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple medical complications. The patient requires close monitoring and treatment of his underlying conditions to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma who underwent a repeat fasciotomy on the right side. The patient was admitted to the ICU due to acute respiratory failure and rhabdomyolysis. Overnight, the patient's PEEP was decreased, and the patient was taken off the ventilator and placed on a trach shield. The patient's CPK levels are trending up, and fluids with bicarbonate are being continued to manage the rhabdomyolysis. The patient had a low-grade temperature overnight, and vancomycin was discontinued. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.5°C, heart rate of 81 bpm, and blood pressure of 121/67 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may progress if not properly managed, leading to hypoxia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
2. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's rhabdomyolysis may worsen if not managed properly, leading to acute kidney injury, muscle damage, and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Sepsis: The patient's low-grade temperature and discontinued vancomycin suggest a possible infection, which may progress to sepsis if not recognized and treated promptly.
4. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of multiple myeloma and acute respiratory failure may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, or cardiogenic shock.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's history of multiple myeloma and use of antibiotics may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.
6. Renal Complications: The patient's rhabdomyolysis and potential sepsis may increase the risk of acute kidney injury, which may progress to chronic kidney disease or require dialysis.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's history of multiple myeloma and use of antibiotics may increase the risk of neurological complications, such as seizures, encephalopathy, or peripheral neuropathy.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, respiratory status, and laboratory results to prevent and manage these potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a past medical history of multiple myeloma, who underwent autologous stem cell transplant in 2016. He presented to the ICU with foot pain and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels, which revealed bilateral compartment syndrome with tracheal swelling likely caused by profound hypothyroidism and concurrent statin use. He is currently receiving invasive ventilation and has been treated with various antibiotics.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 88 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 135/65 mmHg. He has a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 97% on a tracheal mask.

The patient's physical examination is notable for his anxious and agitated behavior, refusing to cooperate with the examination. His peripheral vascular examination is limited due to his compartment syndrome.

Laboratory results show elevated levels of CK, troponin-T, and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), as well as abnormal liver function tests (LFTs) and electrolyte levels.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's bilateral compartment syndrome may lead to respiratory failure, which is already being treated with invasive ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's elevated CK levels and abnormal LFTs may indicate sepsis, which needs to be closely monitored and treated promptly.
3. Hypothyroidism: The patient's profound hypothyroidism may lead to further complications, such as decreased cardiac output and respiratory failure, if left untreated.
4. Statin-induced myotoxicity: The patient's statin use may have contributed to his compartment syndrome, and further monitoring is necessary to prevent further myotoxicity.
5. DVT and PE: The patient's prolonged immobility and compartment syndrome may increase his risk of developing deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).
6. Worsening of compartment syndrome: The patient's compartment syndrome may worsen if not treated promptly and effectively, leading to further tissue damage and potential loss of limbs.
7. Cardiac complications: The patient's abnormal LFTs and elevated troponin-T levels may indicate cardiac damage, which needs to be closely monitored and treated promptly.
8. Infections: The patient's immunocompromised state and prolonged hospitalization may increase his risk of developing infections, which needs to be closely monitored and treated promptly.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment & Plan:63 y/o M with PMHX of MM s/p autologous stem cell
   transplant in 05 presented foot pain and elevated CKs taken the OR
   emergently for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome, now s/p cardiac
   arrest and emergency tracheotomy.
   .
   # Resp failure: Pt was transferred to ICU s/p cardiac arrest with
   emergency trach and was initially requiring alot of support from vent
   to maintain oxygenation but now weaning quickly.  There was likely a
   component of negative inspiratory pressure pulm edema as seen by
   perihilar fullness on CXR.  This is also suggested by the fact that pt
   weaning quickly from initially high O2 requirement. Also with some
   increased secretions from emergency trach and blood in airways.
   Etiology of tongue swelling early on [**10-1**] and impressive upper airway
   edema seen by Anesthesia impeding the ability to re-intubate is
   unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 11**] have some component of airway collapse and tongue swelling
   from hypothyroidism. Baseline, pt is a Mallampati class III and may
   have pharyngeal airway collapse complicating picture.  Now have
   definite airway with trach, will hold off on steroids for now given
   immunosuppression.
   - no evidence of right heart strain on echo to suggest PE
   - patient was weaned off ventilator, now just using trach, mental
   status and respiratory drive good
   - continue aggressive suction
   - will need trach cuff change to smaller size which cannot occur until
   7-14 days after initial trach placement
   - Alb/atrovent nebs
   .
   # s/p Cardiac Arrest: Etiology unclear, s/p epinephrine x1, CPR for 3
   minutes, may have been due to acute upper airway swelling and hypoxia
   causing cardiac arrest/bradycardia. Pt had rapid return of perfusing
   rhythm.  There was significant concern for initial poor neurologic
   status post code, however, pt has now had return of neuro function and
   following commands. Suspect that meds given peri code contributed to
   poor neuro status initially, now clearing.
   - persistently low Calcium despite repletion, continue aggressive
   repletion
   - patient is now awake, alert, responsive
   - etiology of arrest likely hypoxia, with upper airway swelling likely
   secondary to myxedema from hypothryoidism
   - echo did not show any evidence of right heart strain, mild LV
   hypertrophy, LVEF 50-55% with dilated aortic root, ascending aorta
   moderately dilated, small pericardial effusion
   - goal is to maintain MAP > 60 and maintain urine output > 100 cc/hr
   # Compartment Syndrome with abscess: Pt has now had definitive surgical
   intervention with fasciotomy and frank pus found after opening
   compartments.  Deep cultures were sent intra-op
   - now s/p fasciotomy to right leg as well for elevated pressures
   - continue Cefepime for skin flora and ?immunocomp state, will cover
   gram negatives until cultures return, then narrow Abx
   - culture data all no growth to date, peeled off vancomycin yesterday,
   will d/c clindamycin todaoy
   - west [**Doctor First Name **] serology pending, stool enterovirus pending, ebv viral
   load, ebv, cmv, hav, hbv, hcv, lyme [**Doctor Last Name 376**] serologies
   - see below for furthru infectious etiology
   - dressing changes per Vascular
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Pt presented with hyponatremia likely  secondary to
   hypothyroidism or from effective volume depletion, in the setting of
   compartment syndomre.
   -hyponatremia improved today
   - continue NS IVF at 100cc/hr
   - urine lytes
 Urea 257 Cr 51 Na 13 K 31
   - serum osms 258
   - continue to treat hypothyroidism, as per endocrine will continue
   current dosing
   .
   # Multiple Myelomma: Pt has been on Revlimid which may have been
   contributing to hypothyroidism on admission.  Anemia & thrombocytopenia
   on admission likely due to marrow suppression from treatment.
   - holding Revlimid currently
   - f/u Onc recs
   .
   # Elevated CK/Rhabdo: This was likely all secondary to compartment
   syndrome with intracompartment abcess, now s/p fasciotomy
   - continue aggressive IVF,  given persistently elevated CKs, previously
   alkalinization of the urine leading to elevated pH, now switched back
   to NS at 100 cc/hr
   - creatine has been stable, no evidence of acute renal failuer,
   follow-up renal recs
   - continue local wound care per vasc
   .
   Infectious work-up: Concern for infection as initial etiology of
   rhabdomylosis, completing full work-up as per ID.
   - wound culture from the OR:
GRAM STAIN (Final [**2165-10-1**]):
      NO POLYMORPHONUCLEAR LEUKOCYTES SEEN.
      NO MICROORGANISMS SEEN.
WOUND CULTURE (Final [**2165-10-3**]):    NO GROWTH.
ANAEROBIC CULTURE (Preliminary):    NO GROWTH.
ACID FAST SMEAR (Final [**2165-10-2**]):
      NO ACID FAST BACILLI SEEN ON DIRECT SMEAR.

FUNGAL CULTURE (Preliminary):
      NO FUNGUS ISOLATED.
      A swab is not the optimal specimen for recovery of mycobacteria or
      filamentous fungi.  A negative result should be interpreted with
      caution.  Whenever possible tissue biopsy or aspirated fluid should
      be submitted.
   -west nile virus pending
   - cmv pending
   Stool viral culture pending
   Throat viral culture pending
   hepC antibody negative
   hep A antibody POS
   from [**2162**], hep B surfaceb Ab +, hep B core antibody POS
   -          sputum culture
 > 25 PMNs, < 10 Epis, 1+ yeast
   -          urine cx  NG
   -          muscle cx from OR
 no virus isolated so far
   # LFT abnormalities: Elevated transaminases & elevated LDH in setting
   of acute rhabdo. Baseline LFTs normal but does have history of +
   hepatitis B in the past, now with + hep A antibody, unclear if IgM or
   IgG at this point.  Etiology of elevated LFTs is either viral vs.
   secondary to rhabdomylsis. Suspect that may continue to worsen today as
   patient is s/p cardiac arrest.
   - hep A antibody [**Last Name (LF) 400**], [**First Name3 (LF) 116**] send for IgM levels
   - LFTs remain elevated in the setting of continued CK elevation, which
   may be muscle only
   - remainder of hep serologies pending
   - ID work- up as above
   - tox screen negative
   .
   # Anemia: Hct was 34.7 on admission, which has trended down .This is
   likely complicated by underlying abnormal bone marrow on revlimid for
   MM and intra-operative blood loss.
   - will continue to transfuse and try to maintainhct>25
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: Pt profoundly hypothyroid with TSH>50 and low T4.
   This may be contributing to tongue swelling on admission.
   -          continue Levothyroxine 200mg IV daily
   -          think that profound hypothyroidism in the context of statin
   use may have caused presentation

   # FEN:

t have his dentures
   - can advance diet to dysphagic once patient has dentures

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a past medical history of multiple myeloma who presented with foot pain and elevated CK levels. He was found to have bilateral compartment syndrome and tracheal swelling likely secondary to profound hypothyroidism and concurrent statin use. He underwent emergency fasciotomy and was intubated due to respiratory failure. He suffered a cardiac arrest and was resuscitated with epinephrine and CPR. He was transferred to the ICU and is currently on invasive ventilation, with a tracheostomy in place.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is weaning off the ventilator and is currently using a tracheostomy.
* Neurological: He is awake, alert, and responsive, with a decreased mental status.
* Cardiovascular: He has a normal heart rhythm, with a MAP of 60 and a urine output of 100 cc/hr.
* Hemodynamic: He is receiving aggressive fluid repletion and has a normal blood pressure.
* Infections: He has a wound infection, with a negative culture, and is being treated with antibiotics.
* Laboratory results: He has elevated CK levels, with a peak of 116 mg/dL, and is being treated with aggressive IV fluids and repletion of electrolytes.
* Other medical issues: He has hypothyroidism, with a TSH level of 50 and low T4 levels, and is being treated with Levothyroxine 200mg IV daily.

Potential medical complications:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for respiratory failure due to his underlying condition and the use of invasive ventilation.
* Neurological complications: The patient is at risk for neurological complications due to his decreased mental status and the use of sedatives.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient is at risk for cardiovascular complications due to his underlying condition and the use of vasopressors.
* Infections: The patient is at risk for infections due to his wound infection and the use of invasive devices.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient is at risk for complications related to his hypothyroidism, such as heart failure and arrhythmias.
* Rhabdomyolysis: The patient is at risk for further rhabdomyolysis due to his underlying condition and the use of certain medications.

Recommendations:

* Continue aggressive fluid repletion and electrolyte replacement to prevent further complications.
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his ventilation settings as needed.
* Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust his sedation and analgesia as needed.
* Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status closely and adjust his vasopressor settings as needed.
* Continue to treat the patient's wound infection and monitor for signs of sepsis.
* Continue to monitor the patient's thyroid function and adjust his medication as needed.
* Consider transferring the patient to a step-down unit or a regular floor bed once his respiratory status has improved and he is able to tolerate a regular diet.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma who presented with foot pain and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels. He was found to have bilateral compartment syndrome with tracheal swelling likely secondary to profound hypothyroidism and concurrent statin use. The patient had a cardiac arrest and required emergency tracheotomy. He was transferred to the ICU where he was intubated and required mechanical ventilation. He was weaned off the ventilator and is now receiving oxygen therapy through a tracheostomy. The patient's mental status has decreased, and he is refusing to cooperate with the examination.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient had a cardiac arrest, and there is a risk of recurrent cardiac arrest.
3. Compartment syndrome: The patient has had compartment syndrome, and there is a risk of recurrent compartment syndrome.
4. Infection: The patient has had a tracheotomy and may be at risk of developing an infection.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient has profound hypothyroidism, and there is a risk of worsening hypothyroidism.
6. Anemia: The patient has anemia, and there is a risk of worsening anemia.
7. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient has had rhabdomyolysis, and there is a risk of recurrent rhabdomyolysis.
8. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, and there is a risk of worsening hyponatremia.
9. LFT abnormalities: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, and there is a risk of worsening liver dysfunction.
10. HIV testing: The patient's HIV status is unknown, and there is a risk of HIV infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide mechanical ventilation as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and provide cardiopulmonary resuscitation as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's compartment syndrome and provide treatment as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's infection risk and provide antibiotic therapy as needed.
5. Continue to treat the patient's hypothyroidism with levothyroxine.
6. Continue to transfuse the patient's anemia.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's rhabdomyolysis and provide treatment as needed.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's hyponatremia and provide treatment as needed.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's LFT abnormalities and provide treatment as needed.
10. Consider HIV testing for the patient.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma (MM) who underwent autologous stem cell transplantation in 2002. He presented with foot pain and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels and was found to have bilateral compartment syndrome with tracheal swelling likely secondary to profound hypothyroidism and concurrent statin use.

The patient's condition has been complicated by several medical issues, including:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient required invasive ventilation due to cardiac arrest and emergency tracheotomy. He is now weaning quickly from the ventilator.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient experienced cardiac arrest due to upper airway swelling and hypoxia, which was likely secondary to myxedema from hypothyroidism. He received epinephrine and CPR for 3 minutes and had a rapid return of perfusing rhythm.
3. Compartment syndrome with abscess: The patient had a deep abscess in his right leg, which was treated with fasciotomy and drainage. He also had elevated pressures in his left leg, which was treated with fasciotomy.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient presented with hyponatremia likely secondary to hypothyroidism or effective volume depletion. His urine output is currently good.
5. Elevated CK/Rhabdo: The patient had elevated CK levels likely secondary to compartment syndrome with intracompartment abscess. He is being treated with aggressive IV fluids and alkalinization of the urine.
6. Anemia: The patient has anemia likely due to marrow suppression from Revlimid therapy for MM.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient has profound hypothyroidism with TSH > 50 and low T4. He is being treated with Levothyroxine 200mg IV daily.
8. LFT abnormalities: The patient has elevated transaminases and LDH likely secondary to acute rhabdo. His baseline LFTs are normal, but he has a history of hepatitis B in the past.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status could deteriorate, requiring further invasive ventilation or non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV).
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac status could worsen, requiring further interventions such as cardioversion or implantation of a pacemaker.
3. Infection: The patient's wound could become infected, requiring further antibiotics and surgical debridement.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated CK levels could lead to acute kidney injury (AKI), requiring further management with dialysis.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism could worsen, requiring further adjustments to his thyroid medication.
6. LFT abnormalities: The patient's LFT abnormalities could worsen, requiring further management with antiviral therapy and/or corticosteroids.

The patient's current medications include:

1. Levothyroxine 200mg IV daily
2. Cefepime 2g IV q8h
3. Clindamycin 600mg IV q8h
4. Famotidine 20mg IV q8h
5. Metoprolol 25mg IV q8h
6. Albuterol 2.5mg IV q4h
7. Atropine 0.5mg IV q4h
8. Dobutamine 5mcg/kg/min IV

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient's mental status improved overnight, and they are currently awake and alert. They have a history of rhabdomyolysis, likely secondary to statins in the background of hypothyroidism. The patient is no longer requiring invasive ventilation, and their respiratory status is stable. Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU who has undergone several interventions and has a complex medical condition. The patient's mental status has changed overnight, and their vital signs are being closely monitored. 

The patient has a history of rhabdomyolysis, likely secondary to statins, and hypothyroidism, for which they are receiving treatment. They also have an unknown infection (ID) for which antibiotics are being de-escalated. 

The patient's laboratory results show elevated levels of creatine phosphokinase (CPK), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and troponin-T, indicating ongoing muscle damage and potential cardiac injury. Their coagulation profile is abnormal, with elevated levels of D-dimer and fibrinogen, suggesting a hypercoagulable state. 

The patient's fluid balance is being closely monitored, with a net positive balance of 3,581 mL over the past 24 hours. Their respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 98% on a tracheal mask. 

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Progressive rhabdomyolysis leading to acute kidney injury and cardiac dysfunction.
2. Worsening of hypothyroidism, potentially leading to decreased cardiac function and increased risk of infections.
3. Development of sepsis or septic shock due to the unknown infection (ID).
4. Increased risk of bleeding due to the hypercoagulable state and potential coagulopathy.
5. Respiratory failure due to prolonged mechanical ventilation.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to the patient's underlying cardiac condition.
7. Kidney injury or failure due to rhabdomyolysis and potential sepsis.

It is essential to continue monitoring the patient's condition closely and adjusting their treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

   Assessment & Plan:63 y/o M with PMHX of MM s/p autologous stem cell

   arrest and emergency tracheotomy.
   # Resp failure: Pt was transferred to ICU s/p cardiac arrest with
   emergency trach and was initially requiring alot of support from vent
   to maintain oxygenation but now weaning quickly.  There was likely a
   component of negative inspiratory pressure pulm edema as seen by
   perihilar fullness on CXR.  This is also suggested by the fact that pt
   weaning quickly from initially high O2 requirement. Also with some
   increased secretions from emergency trach and blood in airways.

   edema seen by Anesthesia impeding the ability to re-intubate is
   unclear. [**Name2 (NI) 11**] have some component of airway collapse and tongue swelling
   from hypothyroidism. Baseline, pt is a Mallampati class III and may
   have pharyngeal airway collapse complicating picture.  Now have
   definite airway with trach, will hold off on steroids for now given
   immunosuppression.
   - no evidence of right heart strain on echo to suggest PE
   - patient was weaned off ventilator, now just using trach, mental
   status and respiratory drive good
   - continue aggressive suction

   7-14 days after initial trach placement
   - Alb/atrovent nebs
   # s/p Cardiac Arrest: Etiology unclear, s/p epinephrine x1, CPR for 3
   minutes, may have been due to acute upper airway swelling and hypoxia
   causing cardiac arrest/bradycardia. Pt had rapid return of perfusing
   rhythm.  There was significant concern for initial poor neurologic
   status post code, however, pt has now had return of neuro function and
   following commands. Suspect that meds given peri code contributed to

   - persistently low Calcium despite repletion, continue aggressive

   - patient is now awake, alert, responsive

   secondary to myxedema from hypothryoidism
   - echo did not show any evidence of right heart strain, mild LV
   hypertrophy, LVEF 50-55% with dilated aortic root, ascending aorta

   - goal is to maintain MAP > 60 and maintain urine output > 100 cc/hr
   # Compartment Syndrome with abscess: Pt has now had definitive surgical

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications that can arise:

Patient's Condition:

* The patient is a 63-year-old male who presented with profound hypothyroidism, likely leading to bilateral compartment syndrome, laryngeal swelling, and cardiac arrest.
* He underwent emergent tracheotomy and was transferred to the ICU.
* The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and is weaning off oxygen support.
* He has a history of multiple myeloma, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels.
* The patient is also being treated for suspected infection, including wound cultures and serologies.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is a concern due to his history of cardiac arrest and upper airway swelling. He may require continued mechanical ventilation and oxygen support.
2. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and hypothyroidism may increase his risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
3. Neurological Complications: The patient's hypothyroidism and cardiac arrest may increase his risk for neurological complications, such as seizures, stroke, or encephalopathy.
4. Infection: The patient's wound cultures and serologies are pending, and he may require continued antibiotic therapy.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may require continued IV fluid therapy and electrolyte management.
6. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's elevated CK levels may require continued IV fluid therapy and electrolyte management to prevent further muscle damage.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may require continued transfusion support.
8. Hepatitis: The patient's elevated liver enzymes and hepatitis B surface antibody positivity may indicate a viral hepatitis infection.
9. Thyroid Function: The patient's profound hypothyroidism may require continued thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation and oxygen support as needed.
2. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and consider echocardiography to assess for cardiac complications.
3. Continue IV fluid therapy and electrolyte management to prevent further muscle damage and maintain hydration.
4. Monitor the patient's neurological status and consider neuroimaging to assess for neurological complications.
5. Continue antibiotic therapy and wound care as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's thyroid function and adjust thyroid hormone replacement therapy as necessary.
7. Consider transfer to a step-down unit or floor once the patient's condition stabilizes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma (MM) who presented with foot pain and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels. He was taken emergently to the operating room (OR) for fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome, and during the procedure, frank pus was found, indicating an abscess.

The patient's condition has been complicated by a cardiac arrest, which was likely caused by hypoxia secondary to upper airway swelling and myxedema from hypothyroidism. He has also developed rhabdomyolysis, which is likely related to the compartment syndrome and abscess.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated CK and LDH levels, as well as abnormal liver function tests (LFTs), which may be related to viral hepatitis or rhabdomyolysis. His thyroid function tests show profound hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to his tongue swelling and upper airway edema.

The patient has been treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, clindamycin, and cefepime, as well as steroids and other medications. He has also undergone surgical interventions, including fasciotomy and tracheotomy.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Infection: The patient has been treated with antibiotics, but the possibility of infection remains, particularly in the setting of an abscess and rhabdomyolysis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac arrest may have caused long-term damage, and he may be at risk for cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and rhabdomyolysis may have caused neurological damage, and he may be at risk for long-term neurological sequelae.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal distension and hypoactive bowel sounds may indicate gastrointestinal obstruction or ileus, which could lead to further complications.
6. Wound complications: The patient's wounds may become infected or develop further complications, such as dehiscence or evisceration.
7. Endocrine complications: The patient's hypothyroidism may require ongoing management, and he may be at risk for complications related to thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
8. Hematological complications: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia may require ongoing transfusions and management, and he may be at risk for bleeding complications.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires ongoing monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 63-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU after a cardiac arrest and emergency tracheotomy. He has a history of multiple myeloma, hypothyroidism, and has undergone an autologous stem cell transplant. He presented with foot pain and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels, which led to an emergency fasciotomy and frank pus was found in the compartments. He was also found to have compartment syndrome with abscess, and deep cultures were sent. He has been weaned off the ventilator and is now on a tracheostomy. He has been diagnosed with hyponatremia, elevated CK levels, and LFT abnormalities, and is being treated for hypothyroidism and compartment syndrome.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still unstable, and he may require further support with oxygen therapy or mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiac arrest: The patient's cardiac arrest was likely due to hypoxia and upper airway swelling, and he may be at risk for another cardiac arrest if his respiratory status deteriorates.
3. Compartment syndrome: The patient's compartment syndrome has been treated with fasciotomy, but he may still be at risk for further complications, such as muscle necrosis or infection.
4. Infection: The patient's wound culture has been negative, but he may still be at risk for infection, particularly with gram-negative organisms.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism is being treated with levothyroxine, but he may still be at risk for further complications, such as myxedema coma.
6. Rhabdomyolysis: The patient's rhabdomyolysis is being treated with aggressive IV fluids and electrolyte repletion, but he may still be at risk for further complications, such as acute renal failure.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is being treated with transfusions, but he may still be at risk for further complications, such as bleeding or infection.
8. LFT abnormalities: The patient's LFT abnormalities are being monitored, but he may still be at risk for further complications, such as liver failure or bleeding.
9. Hepatitis: The patient has a history of hepatitis B and is currently positive for hepatitis A antibody, and may be at risk for further complications, such as liver failure or bleeding.
10. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutritional status is being monitored, but he may still be at risk for further complications, such as malnutrition or dehydration.

Overall, the patient is at risk for multiple medical complications, and close monitoring and aggressive treatment are necessary to prevent further complications and improve his outcome.

Based on the patient's 24-hour progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

**Summary:**

The patient, a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma, underwent an emergency tracheotomy after a pulseless arrest. He has been extubated and is currently receiving oxygen therapy through a tracheostomy mask. The patient has had a fasciotomy and debridement of the right leg due to compartment syndrome with abscess. He has also undergone a fasciotomy of the left leg. The patient's laboratory results show elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels, which may be related to compartment syndrome, hypothyroidism, or other etiologies.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Respiratory failure:** The patient's respiratory status is still precarious, and he may require continued oxygen therapy and suctioning.
2. **Elevated CK/Rhabdo:** The patient's CK levels are still elevated, which may indicate ongoing muscle damage or rhabdomyolysis.
3. **Compartment syndrome with abscess:** The patient has had surgical intervention, but the possibility of recurrent abscesses or compartment syndrome remains.
4. **Hypothyroidism:** The patient's thyroid function tests are improving, but he may require continued levothyroxine therapy.
5. **Anemia:** The patient's anemia may be related to underlying bone marrow suppression from Revlimid therapy or intra-operative blood loss.
6. **Thrombocytopenia:** The patient's platelet count is still low, which may increase the risk of bleeding.
7. **Infectious etiologies:** The patient's cultures are pending, and he may be at risk for secondary infections, particularly given his immunocompromised state.
8. **Gastrointestinal complications:** The patient's diet is still limited, and he may be at risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as constipation or diarrhea.
9. **Venous thromboembolism (VTE):** The patient is at risk for VTE due to his immobility and underlying medical conditions.
10. **Statin-induced hypothyroidism:** The patient's presentation may have been exacerbated by statin-induced hypothyroidism, which needs to be monitored and managed.

**Recommendations:**

1. Continue aggressive suctioning and oxygen therapy.
2. Monitor the patient's CK levels and respiratory status closely.
3. Continue levothyroxine therapy and monitor thyroid function tests.
4. Manage the patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia with transfusions and supportive care.
5. Continue to monitor for infectious etiologies and manage accordingly.
6. Advance the patient's diet gradually, taking into account his gastrointestinal status.
7. Monitor the patient's VTE risk and consider prophylaxis measures.
8. Consider transferring the patient to the floor today, pending his clinical status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual who suffered a hypoxia/pulseless arrest and required an emergency tracheotomy. The patient has been experiencing sundowning, likely due to increased orientation, and has been combative, requiring restraints.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 90 bpm, blood pressure of 172/88 mmHg, and respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute. The patient's oxygen saturation is 97% on a tracheal mask.

The patient has a dilated small bowel with a diameter of 9 cm, which is likely due to a large bowel movement. The patient's abdominal tenderness has resolved after the bowel movement.

The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and antihypertensives. The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate dehydrogenase, and troponin-T, indicating potential cardiac damage.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their combative behavior, and therefore, the peripheral vascular, skin, neurologic, and other systems have not been assessed.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia/pulseless arrest and emergency tracheotomy put them at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's elevated troponin-T and lactate dehydrogenase levels suggest potential cardiac damage, which can lead to further complications.
3. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's dilated small bowel and abdominal tenderness increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, perforation, or obstruction.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's combative behavior and lack of assessment of their peripheral vascular, skin, neurologic, and other systems increase the risk of neurological complications.
5. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and potential cardiac damage increase the risk of sepsis.
6. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient's anticoagulant therapy increases the risk of bleeding, and their immobilization increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust their treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications that can arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of multiple myeloma (MM) who underwent an autologous stem cell transplant in 2162. He presented with foot pain and elevated creatine kinase (CK) levels, which led to an emergency fasciotomy due to compartment syndrome. He had a cardiac arrest likely secondary to hypoxia and was intubated. He underwent an emergency tracheotomy and subsequent fasciotomy on the other side.

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory failure: Off ventilator, using tracheostomy, and showing good mental status and respiratory drive.
* Elevated CK/rhabdomyolysis: Bilateral fasciotomy was performed, and CK levels are trending down.
* Abdomen: Distended, tympanic, and stooling quite a bit, with a concern for Clostridioides difficile (C. diff).
* Compartment syndrome with abscess: Definitive surgical intervention was performed, and cultures were negative.
* Anemia: Hct is 23.8%, and transfusions are being continued to maintain a hct >25.
* Hypothyroidism: TSH is improving, and Levothyroxine 200mg IV daily is being continued.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. Respiratory failure: The patient may develop respiratory failure due to the prolonged use of the tracheostomy and potential lung damage.
2. C. diff infection: The patient's stooling and abdominal distension may be indicative of a C. diff infection, which could lead to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
3. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are normal, but the prolonged use of diuretics and potential hypovolemia may lead to renal failure.
4. Hypothyroidism: The patient's TSH levels are improving, but the patient may still be at risk for hypothyroidism-related complications, such as bradycardia, hypotension, and decreased cognitive function.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to ongoing blood loss and potential bone marrow suppression from the MM treatment.
6. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and prolonged use of central lines and catheters may increase the risk of infection, including sepsis and multi-organ failure.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal distension and stooling may be indicative of gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac arrest and prolonged use of vasopressors may lead to cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias, hypertension, and cardiac failure.

**Plan:**

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust the tracheostomy as needed.
2. Start empiric treatment for C. diff if the patient's stooling and abdominal distension worsen.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust diuretic therapy as needed.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hypothyroidism with Levothyroxine and monitor TSH levels.
5. Transfuse blood products as needed to maintain a hct >25.
6. Monitor the patient's anemia and adjust treatment accordingly.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's infection risk and adjust antibiotic therapy as needed.
8. Monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust treatment accordingly.
9. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust vasopressor therapy as needed.

   cell transplant in [**2162**] presented with foot pain and elevated CK taken
   to OR emergently for fasciotomy due to to compartment syndrome, now s/p
   cardiac arrest likely secondary to hypoxia, emergent tracheotomy and
   subsequent fasciotomy on the other side.
   24 Hour Events:
   Yesterday, CKs continued to trend down, yesterday 9000. Fluids were
   stopped yesterday. Patient had some delirium overnight on Saturday
   night but mental status was improved yesterday. Patient got 10 mg IV
   lasix yesterday to meet diuresis goals. Likely ready to call out today.
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Cefipime - [**2165-10-4**] 08:00 AM
